Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Localizing the translational machinery of an obligate symbiosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Endosymbiosis is a process whereby one cell takes up stable residence within another cell, occasionally allowing the new consortia to harness previously unexploited resources. For example, plants are able to use the Sun's energy because of an ancient endosymbiosis between a bacterium and a eukaryotic cell. Similarly, many sap-feeding insects-some of which are devastating crop pests-rely on bacterial endosymbionts to survive. Insect endosymbioses are useful models because they are of an intermediate age: old enough to show many parallels to mitochondria and chloroplasts, but recent enough to retain a clear bacterial character. Studying insect-bacterial symbioses thus provide insight into the forces and mechanisms involved in establishing and maintaining bacteria-host relationships. This proposal includes outreach through a children's science program to teach about bacterial symbioses.

Obligate insect endosymbionts have highly reduced genomes that have lost many genes compared to their free-living ancestors. Similar to organelles, some endosymbiont genomes contain fewer genes than thought necessary to support cellular life. This project will use the cicada endosymbiont Hodgkinia as a model to study how symbionts with reduced genomes function with so few genes. The PIs will investigate the structure and function of Hodgkinia-supporting insect tissues using a combination of cutting edge light and electron microscopy, with the aim of better understanding if and/or how insect hosts provide symbionts with essential cellular components. The awardee will answer these questions by labeling cicada proteins and RNAs to localize these gene products within symbiont-harboring tissues. The results of this study are important for understanding host-bacterial interactions, the evolution of organelles, and for improving microscopy methods on insect tissues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Many insects live in an obligate symbiosis with bacteria. Sometimes these bacteria live exclusively inside of insect cells and synthesize nutrients that their insect hosts cannot make on their own or obtain from their food. Genome sequencing of many of these bacteria has suggested that they rely on their hosts not only for basic metabolites, but also for cellular machinery for essential processes such as protein production. This project sought to use microscopy to localize various host products to assess the role of the host in symbiont protein production. We analyzed the gene expression patterns of the host and chose proteins that are upregulated in the tissue supporting the symbioses and that were missing from the bacterial genomes. Using fluorescence microscopy, we showed that these proteins are at high concentrations in host cells, but much lower or negligible in bacterial symbiont cells. Confirmatory studies using more powerful imaging techniques are underway. These experiments will help us define interactions between bacterial symbionts and their hosts, and could question the features typically though to distinguish cellular organelles from intracellular bacteria.

Broader Impacts: Over the two-year duration of this award, one graduate student, two postdoctoral scientists, and several undergraduate students have worked on this project. As a graduate student, this award provided me with experience essential for success as a research scientist. I learned grantsmanship, budgeting and managerial skills, and gained independent research experience. While this project was started to complete my doctoral dissertation, it grew in scope and significance, such that one postdoctoral scientist continues to work on the results I started during my PhD. The development of these methods has been challenging, and have allowed me to train and collaborate with scientists at institutions in three states. I have trained from microscopy experts at Montana State University, Oregon Health and Sciences University, and Washington State University. Lastly, I have participated in various outreach activities during this award, including organizing science-related events for K-12 students and the general public.
